instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.P5VS5_EN: What is P5VS5_EN? P5VS5_EN is a signal that turns on the PP5V_S5 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_REG: What is PP3V3_S5_REG? PP3V3_S5_REG is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> liquid damage, very recent no corrosion.

Customer says they heared a pop and that was it, no power.

All S5 fluctiuating.
<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> = On / Off
<SIGNAL>P5VS5_EN</SIGNAL> = On / Off

Schematic is leading me back to the SMC

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: PPBUS stable and at what voltage?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12V steady.
PP3V42 is steady 3.42

Tried injecting 3.3V into 3v3 and 5v S5 enables just to see what happens. Got 5V S5 rail but no 3V S5 and again, no S0... Thought it could be worth a shot but no cigar.
Removed the wire now.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> should be 12.6V.....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 6000"]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> should be 12.6V.....[/QUOTE]

Yes, sorry it's 12.6v exactly.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: Resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> bus? Was there corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6011"]Resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> bus? Was there corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>?[/QUOTE]

What point should I measure from? EDIT:  <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> shows up all over. Not sure where you want me to take a measurement from.
Absoluetly no corrosion at all. spill only 2 weeks ago

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: Duke said 3V3_[COLOR=#FF0000]S5[/COLOR] bus not S3, measurement can be taken at any point where <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> bus is present.....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
From <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> to ground = ~ 16K
Just noticed that <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> (connecting to <SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_L</SIGNAL> through 1M <RESISTOR>R5002</RESISTOR>) = 1.2v .... This isn't right is it?

Sorry, feeling my way in the dark here

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="aprendiz, post: 6025"]Duke said 3V3_[COLOR=#FF0000]S5[/COLOR] bus not S3, measurement can be taken at any point where <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> bus is present.....[/QUOTE]

Sorry, typo I ment S5. I understand S5 is off state and S3 is one of the sleeps. S5 will be on while machine is off.... I just hit the wrong number key. Will have to be sure to read everything with care before I hit the post button.

Thanks

From <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> to ground = ~ 16K

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6011"]Resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> bus? Was there corrosion around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>?[/QUOTE]

Yes, sorry it's 12.6v exactly.
From <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_REG</SIGNAL> to ground = 16K

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> should be 3.42V as it comes straight from 3V42 bus. So pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R5002</RESISTOR> should have 3.42V

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6056"]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> should be 3.42V as it comes straight from 3V42 bus. So pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R5002</RESISTOR> should have 3.42V[/QUOTE]

Thank you for taking the time to reply to help

I was being a F* moron and probing the wrong point. 3V42 is good.

<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> both kick out the right voltage for a split second as the enable signal is sent from SMC but when injecting enable signals, only <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> turns on (tripple chacked I was probing the right point) so if <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> was being pulled low for some reason then there would not be 3v3 at any point right.

There must be [I]something [/I]telling the SMC to turn off the S5 enable surely?

I tried probing at <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> in case they play any part.

Not a clue what's going on here... Not a F*ing danny

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: I removed <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> just to see what would happen to the enable signals. Signals are steady after removing the 51980 chip. Guessing something is turning on and telling the SMC to stop the enable signals.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: Replace it with a known good one now.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6080"]Replace it with a known good one now.[/QUOTE]

Tried that, still the same thng... So then I removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8020</TRANSISTOR> controlling <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_FET</SIGNAL> rail and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is stable. when <TRANSISTOR>Q8020</TRANSISTOR> is on the board (or off) there is no power getting to the SPI ROM. I went through every single resistor and capacitor and IC removing systematically replacing everything on node 141 (or "short") in TestLink. I'll try removing <TRANSISTOR>Q8002</TRANSISTOR> which controls the <TRANSISTOR>Q8020</TRANSISTOR> gate just to see what happens.

I tried jumpering 3v42 over to SPI ROM VDD (which is on node 141) directly from PP3V42 but just ended in 3V42 pulled low and (obviously) no green / orange MagSafe.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: Isn't the board trying to power on and running into a short and shutting down? Are any of the S0 busses coming high for a second?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6080"]Replace it with a known good one now.[/QUOTE]

Tried that still the same thng...

I tried jumpering 3v42 over to SPI ROM VDD (which is on node 141) directly from PP3V42 but just ended in 3V42 pulled low and (obviously) no green / orange MagSafe.

So then I removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8020</TRANSISTOR> controlling <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_FET</SIGNAL> rail and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> directly from <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is stable. When <TRANSISTOR>Q8020</TRANSISTOR> is on the board (or off the board) there is no power getting to the SPI ROM (pni 8 VDD on node 141). I'll try removing <TRANSISTOR>Q8002</TRANSISTOR> which controls the <TRANSISTOR>Q8020</TRANSISTOR> gate to see what happens.

I went through every single resistor and capacitor and IC systematically removing everything on node 141 testing <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> & enables and then replacing the part. I did this to check for anything pulling that node low or maybe a bad cap but no joy.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
I don't have any  A143DJ mosfets or anything else in the right package so I've ordered in a batch from mouser.
Will have to wait a couple days to see if i makes any difference to replace them.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: I have no idea what you are trying to do but did you check <SIGNAL>PP3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL> comes high? If yes it should pull the gate of <TRANSISTOR>Q8020</TRANSISTOR> to pretty much 0V.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6102"]I have no idea what you are trying to do[/QUOTE]

Yeah, that would be a fair comment.

[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6102"] you check <SIGNAL>PP3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL> comes high? If yes it should pull the gate of <TRANSISTOR>Q8020</TRANSISTOR> to pretty much 0V.[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>PP3V3SUS_EN</SIGNAL> only shows up if <TRANSISTOR>Q8002</TRANSISTOR> is removed. When <TRANSISTOR>Q8002</TRANSISTOR> is on the board the voltage at <TRANSISTOR>Q8002</TRANSISTOR> gate changes by a couple hunded millivolts and <TRANSISTOR>Q8020</TRANSISTOR> gate goes high low high low.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: What should I be testing as the cause of this on off S5 rail problem do you think?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: You didn't answer the question from post #17. The board is power cycling and I bet all S0 busses are coming high for a second. Check closer.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6120"]You didn't answer the question from post #17. The board is power cycling and I bet all S0 busses are coming high for a second. Check closer.[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 217mV
3.7k to ground

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 200mV
9.2k to ground

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: Are they pulsing? Most multimeters are too slow to catch it, better to use a scope.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6124"]Are they pulsing? Most multimeters are too slow to catch it, better to use a scope.[/QUOTE]

They are indeed pulsing.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> by ~ 2.5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> by ~ 500mV

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: Is CPU Vcore pulsing too? Check all coils for shorts.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6139"]Is CPU Vcore pulsing too? Check all coils for shorts.[/QUOTE]

No voltage on vcore at all, not even a spike on the scope.

Diode DMM
L7310, L7320, L7330, L9360, L9330 = 0.005V drop to ground
L7520 = 0.000

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message: Uhm, there is a short to GND on L7520? That is at least one problem to fix first. Inject some voltage and see what heats up.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> unstable S5 enables
threads.message:
Wow, what a prize fucking moron I am... Ahh jeez. Yes, clearly short to ground but I spent ages searching for the problem going through the schematic around in circles and you say, test S0 rails, check for a short, throw in some watts and see what burns your fingers.... And it's fixed! :) Thanks for sticking with me.

It was a cap USB switch.
